easy.title: Easy Level - The Basics
easy.description: Perfect for beginners. Basic concepts and fundamentals.
easy.readingMaterial:
GenLayer is a new protocol that changes how blockchains work by using Intelligent Contracts. Unlike traditional blockchains (like Ethereum) that are limited to rigid code, GenLayer integrates AI (Artificial Intelligence) directly at the protocol level.

Key Differences:

Web Access: Traditional chains need 'oracles' (middlemen) to see the internet. GenLayer contracts can fetch live web data natively.

Language: GenLayer uses Python, making it accessible to millions of developers, unlike Solidity which is niche.

Understanding: These contracts can understand natural language (human commands), not just binary code.

questions.question: GenLayer contracts are different because they are:
What programming language does GenLayer primarily use to lower the barrier to entry?
How does GenLayer interact with the internet?
options: It natively fetches live web data
It asks the user to copy-paste data

questions.question: What is the specific name of GenLayer's smart contracts?
GenLayer is designed for:
Traditional smart contracts are limited because:
options: They can't access the outside world without oracles
They are too easy to write

questions.question: GenLayer Intelligent Contracts can interpret:
Which consensus mechanism validates the output in GenLayer?
What does the Python-based SDK allow?
options: It lowers the barrier to entry for developers

questions.question: A key vision of GenLayer is to merge:

medium.title: Medium Level - The Features & Use Cases
medium.description: For those familiar with blockchain and AI concepts.
medium.readingMaterial:
GenLayer's Intelligent Contracts leverage LLMs to process natural language and fetch off-chain data.

Intelligent vs. Traditional:

Traditional: Static logic, relies on Oracles, strictly deterministic.

Intelligent: Adaptable logic, No Oracles needed, handles non-deterministic outputs via Optimistic Democracy.

Use Cases:

Prediction Markets: Decentralized trading on future events (Sports, Finance).

Performance-Based Contracting: Automates payments based on verified real-time deliverables.

Dispute Resolution: AI-driven arbitration that expedites case handling.

Network States: Decentralized governance frameworks.

questions.question: Intelligent Contracts are distinct because they leverage:
How does GenLayer handle external data compared to Ethereum?
options: It integrates directly with real-time web data (No Oracles)
It uses a decentralized oracle network (DON)
It requires a trusted multi-sig bridge
It uses optimistic rollups to batch data

questions.question: For "Performance-Based Contracting," what triggers the release of funds?
options: A multi-signature approval from the board
The expiration of a time-lock contract
Intelligent Contracts tracking deliverables in real-time
A manual submission of a PDF invoice

questions.question: What advantage does GenLayer offer for Dispute Resolution?
options: It uses a jury of random token holders (Kleros style)
It freezes assets until a local court rules
It reverts the transaction entirely to prevent disputes
It utilizes AI-driven arbitration to reduce costs and latency

questions.question: GenLayer's consensus "Optimistic Democracy" is capable of validating:
In the context of GenLayer, "Network States" refers to:
options: The status of the blockchain connection (Online/Offline)
Sharding the network into different states

questions.question: Why is Python chosen over Solidity for GenLayer?
options: Python executes faster on the EVM
Python allows for larger block sizes
Python is the native language of AI and Data Science

questions.question: What is the primary function of AI-Driven DAOs on GenLayer?
options: To mint tokens automatically based on inflation
To prevent users from selling tokens
To manage real-time governance and data-informed investments

questions.question: Traditional contracts are described as "Static". How are Intelligent Contracts described?
Who validates the non-deterministic outputs in GenLayer?
options: The original developer of the contract
The end-user via a wallet signature

questions.question: GenLayer removes the need for "Oracles". What are Oracles typically used for?
options: Bridging off-chain data to on-chain environments

questions.question: Which of these is a listed use case for GenLayer?
What limits traditional contracts regarding "Language Understanding"?
options: They can only process English text
They are limited to code-based commands

questions.question: How do Intelligent Contracts verify performance in a contract?
options: By trusting the vendor's API blindly
By waiting for a user to upload a screenshot
By checking the wallet balance only

questions.question: The GenLayer SDK is described as:
options: A Rust crate for systems engineering

hard.title: Hard Level - The Mechanics
hard.description: Expert level with advanced technical questions.
hard.readingMaterial:
Optimistic Democracy is GenLayer's consensus mechanism, rooted in Condorcet's Jury Theorem.

The Process:

Submission: User sends transaction.

Leader Proposes: A randomly chosen Leader validator processes it and proposes a result.

Validators Recompute: A committee of validators re-computes. They approve/deny based on whether the output aligns (is equivalent) with the Leader's.

Result Accepted: Once a majority approves, the result is provisionally accepted.

Appeal: During the Finality Window, a participant can dispute by posting a bond.

Additional Validation: If appealed, a new set of validators re-evaluates.

Resolution: Valid appeal = Appellant rewarded. Invalid appeal = Bond forfeited.

questions.question: Optimistic Democracy is rooted in which theoretical framework?
What specifically does Condorcet's Jury Theorem affirm regarding GenLayer?
options: Consensus speed increases as node count decreases
The probability of a fork decreases with block height
A supermajority is required to override a leader
Collective decision-making accuracy improves as independent validators vote

questions.question: How is the "Leader" validator selected for a transaction?
options: Round-robin rotation based on slot number
Weighted probability based on staked tokens

questions.question: What is the specific role of the Committee after the Leader proposes a result?
options: They verify the cryptographic signature of the proposal
They attest to the data availability

questions.question: The Committee approves or denies the Leader's proposal based on:
options: Whether the resulting state root hash matches
Whether the gas limit was respected
Whether the transaction format is valid
Whether the output aligns (is equivalent) with the Leader's result

questions.question: At what specific stage is a result considered "Provisionally Accepted"?
options: When the Leader broadcasts the proposal
When a majority of the committee approves
When the block is finalized on L1

questions.question: What must a participant do to initiate a dispute?
The specific timeframe allowed for appeals is called the:
If an appeal is filed, how is the dispute resolved?
options: The original committee re-votes with higher weight
A new set of validators is chosen to re-evaluate
The transaction is reverted to the mempool

questions.question: What is the exact penalty for an invalid appeal?
options: The bond is distributed to the Leader

questions.question: Optimistic Democracy is designed to validate outputs that are:
Why does GenLayer need a unique consensus like Optimistic Democracy?
options: Because Python is slower than Solidity
Because AI models and Web Data can be non-deterministic

questions.question: In the "Comparison" table, Traditional Smart Contracts are limited by:
What happens to the appellant if the appeal is found to be VALID?
options: They get their bond back only (no reward)

questions.question: The GenLayer documentation states that the protocol integrates AI:
Which phase comes immediately after "Validators Recompute"?
Under Optimistic Democracy, the system assumes the Leader's result is correct unless:
options: The gas price is too low
The committee denies it or an appeal is triggered

questions.question: "Intelligent Contracts" are best defined as:
options: Self-executing programs with terms defined in code
Mutable smart contracts controlled by a DAO
AI-driven contracts that access web data and process natural language

questions.question: What enables GenLayer to "Bridging multiple ecosystems"?
The "Interactive Model" mentioned in the docs relates to:
